content: I saw someone mention kripke semantics stuff in the context of probability and/or measure theory earlier (in another place) and it got me wondering
can you apply that somehow to automatically account for all of the "almosts" and "this is actually technically an equivalence class"?
feels like maybe you're doing some kind of implicit shift to a smaller almost-everywhere set or something, the kind of thing where kripke semantics automatically moves you down some worlds
or equivalently (?), maybe you're talking about some kind of germ

Idk about Kripke semantics, but if you have a measure space (X,F,μ)(X, \mathcal F, \mu)(X,F,μ), the topos of sheaves on F/ker⁡μ\mathcal F / \ker \muF/kerμ has an 'almost everywhere on F\mathcal FF' internal logic. In other words: on ShF\mathrm{Sh}\mathcal FShF, there's a Lawvere-Tierney topology which corresponds to the 'almost everywhere' modality, and the closed sheaves for this topology are exactly the shaves on F/ker⁡μ\mathcal F/\ker \muF/kerμ.
Here ker⁡μ={A∈F∣μ(A)=0}\ker \mu = \{ A \in \mathcal F | \mu(A)=0\}kerμ={A∈F∣μ(A)=0}
I'm writing a thesis on this btw :joy:
